If you can, remove any means you might use to harm yourself (medication, sharp objects, firearms) or ask someone you trust to help do this for you.
If you are with someone now, let them know you need help and ask them to stay with you. If you are alone, consider going to the nearest emergency department or calling emergency services.
You matter and help is available. If you can, please call emergency services or a local crisis line right now — and if you want specific numbers, tell me your country and I will provide them.

Imagine you are on a quiet beach. With every inhale, hear the gentle waves. With every exhale, feel your stress wash away.
Try a body scan: Start at your feet and notice any tension. Slowly move your attention up through your body, releasing tension with every exhale.
Count your breaths: Inhale (1), exhale (2), inhale (3), exhale (4)… Continue up to 10. If you lose count, simply start again — no judgment.

Close your eyes and picture a place where you feel safe and relaxed. Breathe slowly and imagine being there, soaking in the peace.

Anxiety disorders are the most common mental health condition, affecting millions worldwide.
Half of all mental health conditions start by age 14, but most cases go undetected and untreated.
Stigma and lack of support prevent many people from seeking mental health care.
Exercise, good sleep, and social connections can significantly improve mental health.

Women are more likely than men to experience anxiety and depression.
Children and adolescents exposed to violence and poverty are at greater risk of mental health problems.
Globally, less than 2% of health budgets are spent on mental health.
Talking openly about mental health can reduce stigma and encourage more people to seek help.
Most people with mental health conditions improve or recover completely with the right support.
Therapy and counseling are proven to help people cope with stress, anxiety, and depression.
Strong friendships and social connections act as a protective factor for mental health.
Spending just 20 minutes in nature can boost mood and reduce stress levels.
Mindfulness and meditation are shown to lower anxiety and improve focus.
Recovery is possible for many — mental health challenges do not define a person.
Positive coping strategies like exercise, journaling, or art therapy can strengthen mental resilience.
People who seek help early often recover faster and more effectively.
Learning about mental health reduces fear and empowers people to support one another.
Every conversation about mental health helps break the stigma and creates hope.
